text: Ar: Toasty, melanoidin-rich malts; raisin and a touch of banana; molasses. Ap: Deep brown, opaque; small light-tan head with low retention, leaves a band of finely bubbled foam aroudn the edge and a nebulous haze across the surface. T: Rich, semi-sweet molasses and toffee; raisin, hints of cocoa, some cherry; medium bitterness with a herbal hop flavor; clean, warming alcohol mingles with the rich melanoidin malts, tasting like oatmeal raisin cookies; more toffee and raisin, plus a bit of char, on the finish. P: Medium-full body with medium-high carbonation; finish is medium. O: Lucious and delicious; a big baltic porter packed with complex and rich malt and caramel flavors; the fruit flavors and alcohol warmth are in great balance, neither becoming overwhelming. decadent from start to finish.

Pours a three finger tan head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Black color, no highlights. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Burnt malt and chocolate nose and flavor is sugary malt but nearly balanced with hop bitterness, nice Baltic porter. Pricey at $9.95 for a 500ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a nearly opaque black color with a frothy tan head. Aroma has a touch of coffee and burnt wood. Flavor is smooth roasted malt, with sweet chocolate and charcoal. Though there is a smoothness to the is, the alcohol hits you quickly. All the sweetness and complexity of a Baltic Porter, and then some. Big, bold and black, as advertised.

Bottle courtesy of GenDV110k+OT, thanks Donnie! Pokal. Deep brown, near black, with small beige head. A: roasted a,t, dark chocolate, earth, wood. Nice. T: rich roasted and sweet malts, molasses, smoke, earth, dark fruit. Fairly rich. Quite good.

Well, pardon me, but Im on a review toot and this is my 8th full pour attempt of the day. I enjoy drinking Zywiec porter, an authentic Baltic, and priced locally at $2.50 for 22 oz. Great deal for a very good brew. Und so, the comparisons begin to this Massachusetts made, slightly more expensive copy of the style. It is also a good one.
Actually, at this point in the evening, Im too aswim to form a clear judgement and articulate it. So I will plagiarize from BA... remember, its not plagiarism if you cite your source, as Melania Trump failed to do when she recited Michelle Obamas speech. "Undated bottle at 42 degrees into a hand washed and dried JK snifter, allowed to warm to 50 degrees. Id have allowed it to warm more, but I was thirstyyyyy.
Aroma  Roasted malt
Head large (Maximum seven cm, aggressive pour), light brown, frothy, diminishing to a three mm frothy ring and partial frothy layer, with some residual foam lacing as the head recedes
Lacing excellent  wide irregular bands of frothy bubbles, mostly tiny but with some small and medium present
Body dark brown/black, opaque
Flavor  mostly roasted malt with a hint of chocolate; no obvious hops, no alcohol, no diacetyl
Palate medium, almost creamy, soft carbonation

A very nice Baltic Porter, slightly on the watery side, lacking the flavor complexity of many others. Hop flavor is absent, true of many other Baltic Porters. This one is so easy drinking that it is almost sessionable, until the 10% alcohol slaps you behind the ear with a sock filled with buckshot. Think Ill have another." Kudos to Ozzylizard, who has unwittingly helped me out. Here I differ since I dont have another and it is time for bed.

Darkest brown in color with a ring of tan foam. Bakers chocolate , roast, and a faint sugar sweetness. Flavor is similar but better - so very balanced with delicious chocolate and roast malt dominating but never dry or acidic. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel and very smooth finish. Well done.
Pours black, ring of head. Aroma is ash, cocoa, and candy sugar. Silky, full body. Sweet. Some bitterness on the finish, but not all that much.
Utterly black with no head. Lovely chocolate aroma. Rich and smooth flavor of coffee-candy with a rich roasted undertone and hints of cocoa. Silky smooth mouthfeel.

Dark brown, a little bubbly. Tan head. Mocha and nutty aroma. Body fairly light, unexpected. Some carbonation. Deep roasty malt flavor, cola, mildly sweet, drier finish. Interesting, the flavors themselves are good not great but complex yet light and drinkable for ABV.

Draft at Milk and Hops-Chelsea. 
Dark brown, creamy light brown head, glass coating lace. Boozy, dark malt aroma. Chocolate and licorice. Smooth, rich mouthfeel.

On draft. This is one seriously well-executed beer. Its packed full of flavors and ingredients, but it manages to stay worryingly balanced and restrained. Even with a high ABV and (Im guessing) a huge malt bill, it drinks light and crisp. Theres a good amount of light chocolate and a bit of toast flavors, but its still deceptively easy drinking, with some more bitterness showing as it warms up. This is stupidly good.
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is chocolate and malt. Taste is sweet chocolate malt with a malty chocolate finish. Good but not memorable.

Bottle. Pours dark brown, with a light brown head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, and oats. Flavor is dominated by chocolate, but theres also malt, along with a bit of hops and alcohol. Medium to heavy body, with a long, chocolatey aftertaste.

Piwo, którego butelką 0.33 spokojnie mógłbym się podzielić, bo jest bardzo obfite w smak i aromat, ale jednak nie czuję, żeby wypicie całej butelki było męczarnią. Bardzo fajny Porter Bałtycki. Potężny zapach, słodkość, karmel, trochę ciemnych owoców, czekolady i kawy, lekkie mam wrażenie orzechy, praktycznie zero paloności w zapachu. W smaku równie bogate, bardzo pełne, naprawdę niemało ciała, bardzo gładkie. W smaku czuć więcej spalenizny, troszeczkę popiołu, ale poza tym fajna czekolada, owoce ciemne, kawowa lekko końcówka. Szkoda tylko, że nad Atlantykiem robią takie Portery Bałtyckie, a nie nad Bałtykiem :P
Bottle. Nose oc chocolate, umami, touch of soy and smoke. Black with lace. Sweet, rich malt flavor, chocolate and cocoa, great body. Loved it.

Bottle shared, thanks! Very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of malt upfront with chocolate, roast and light coffee notes. Flavour is Above moderate sweet and light moderate bitter. Above medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Thought I had rated this before, guess not, thanks for the bottle great gents, rated barrel version but not regular..pours a nice black with 1 finger mocha cream head.nose is oh so nice with quality coffee with a healthy dose of milk lactose sweetness, really nice,mouthfeel is super smooth, creamy with pleasing roasted but essence, wow is that solid,wouldnt mind waking up and pairing Sunday breakfast with one of these every week, abv is guised well, very well done,a cut below barrel aged version but still top notch stuff..

Deep blackish brown body with thin chocolate tan lacing. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with notes of beautiful rich tobacco roast, lush dark chocolate and bitter dry oak. Jacks Abbey FH portfolio is a world class example of how delicious and well-executed the Baltic porter can potentially be as a style.

Aroma:

Medium aroma of malts, caramel, chocolate, roasted malts and coffee.

Appearance:

Opaque black beer with a medium/large head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts with malts, caramel and chocolate; ends slightly bitter and dry with roasted malts and coffee.

Overall:

This beer is intense, complex and balanced. The amount of roasted malts is insane, this is simply an Imperial Stout. We had a sweet one and an almost smoked one, together creating a perfect balance (once again).

This is not a Baltic porter but anyone who cares is dumb. Id say its basically an imperial stout or an imperial porter if you believe such a thing is different than in imperial stout. (Hint: it isnt.) I like this stuff fine. Its got a pretty nice roast grain and chocolate character and is reasonably smooth even though it burns way too much for ten percent. I suppose it is on the lighter bodied side for a big American brew, something along the lines of what youd expect from a well-made Belgian ale of this strength. It is still a bit creamy even though its not too heavy and this helps further bring out the chocolate as well as some cherry/fruity notes. Id say this is definitely above average for a big beer. It is not completely obnoxious but still very flavorful and lends itself to slow sipping w/o being pancake syrup. I will likely never drink this again in my entire life but that goes for all beers so why point it out for this one? I dont know. You tell me.

500 mL bottle shared with ebone1988. Got this in a trade a while back. The pour is a lighter black, light brown color with a thinner cap of light khaki head that falls to a bubbly collar. The aroma is very roasty. Its got the bitterness and heavy roast to go with a light dark chocolate. There is a light molasses and a decent sweetness to it that is pretty appreciated. The flavor is one dimensional. There is a very subdued oxidation up front, but the roast and bitterness really comes charging through. A dark chocolate is present in the back end. Its one dimensional, but its in the right dimension. The mouth feel is excellent. There is a soft carbonation and a nice viscosity. It really clings to the palate and gets a little better as it warms. The chocolate and bitter roast dominate, and thats what tasty in a Baltic.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is roasty, chocolate, coffee, robust malt. Appearance is dark dark brown, light tan head, poured thin-ish. Taste is...light? Really not that much happening. Oxidation. Just some roast that comes in real late. Mouthfeel is decently thick, soft velvety carbonation, the roast came in with a vengeance late in the aftertaste. Overall, this one is pretty disappointing.

Bottle at home. Black pour with fine beige head. Nose is cocoa and some licorice. Tastes of milk chocolate, roasted malt, bitter espresso, some herbal notes, light licorice. Hides alcohol well. Nice creamy yet bitter palate. Ive had several variants glad to have the OG.

Bottle from Acton Wine and Spirits. Dark brown bordering on black with a decent sized tightly bubbled tan head that persists. Chocolate licorice and some faint burnt sugars coupled with some light earth and fruity aromas. Creamy smooth bready pilsner malt is somehow evident with all the darker malt flavors. Chocolate licorice and light fruity flavors offset with just a bit of earthy hops for balance. Ive had many of the barrel treatments for this beer and loved them finally found this to try, its a stand up porter.

Draught at the brewery, 4/23/16.Jesus, these guys put out so many variants Ive never actually taken the time to have the regular version. Finally a chance...Dark, milk chocolate brown with deeper ebony shades and a light tan head atop showing strong retention.Chocolate, very flakey with dark bread and lots of roast. A big caramel character rises up to balance. All of JAs beers are so much softer and approachable lately and I couldnt be happier. Not just another obnoxiously overroasted, overbittered imperial stout/imperial porter/baltic porter, etc.....In the mouth, plenty of dry brown bread balances caramel with milk chocolate and dry roasted notes. Lots of maltiness, with a good attenuation though leaving some residual sugar for body and balance. I dont know if this beer is specifically sweeter because of how much of it gets barrel aged, and maybe its just the placebo effect, but I think it is much better barrel-aged. The malt, chocolate, bread, vanilla, caramel, etc.. really do soak up the tannin and whatever other things are thrown in the barrel. Still, for a barrel aged version to be good, the base beer has to be quite competent. And indeed it is.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2016 Tap into a snifter showing pitch black with a finger and a half of latte colored foam.

The nose shows notes of steel tank and lightly roasted malts.

The palate is light bodied and well carbonated. Flavors of light coffee and roasted malts with light hoppy bitterness that matures into a light latte like bitterness. Well done.

Bottle at home. Aroma is roasted malt, oats, dark chocolate, liquorice, coffee, cocoa, touch of raisins. Flavour is moderate to medium sweet with a roasty bitter finish. Body is medium to full. Very rich Porter, potent roasty chocolate coffee and liquorice aroma.

Pours a dark as a moonless night black from a bottle. Not much of an aroma, just kind of a general roasted sweetness. Flavor is a slightly chocolately, with faint finishes of licorice and dark cherry. Well balanced bitterness and sweetness, hits both sufficiently and well. Very good beer.

Partial to this brewery as I was born in Framingham so Framinghammer was a fun find. Not many porters to my liking, but this one is delicious! Pretty in the glass, head lovely goes great with Beethovens 9th. Look forward to trying it at the brewpub which I Love!!

Bottle. Black pour, thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, licorice, stophoest and slightly silty. Flavor is quite bitter, roasted and somewhat dry. Full bodied and with a very nice balance. Nice brew.

Multiple tastings from bottle and on draft. Noticed that I have never rated this one though it has become a favorite since Jacks Abby came to town. This is one of the best Baltic Porters out there and I love the different twists they come up with. A great brew from a great brewery.

Talk about the cart before the horse, I had the bourbon barrel-ed version years ago, so glad to finally try this gem.
This was poured into an English pint glass.
The appearance was a dark brown almost black color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated nicely. A one finger white foamy head started and dissipated nicely. Messy lacing winds around the glass nicely.
The smell takes in roasty dark, milk and bakers chocolate notes inside of a light bready sticky flavor (lager yeast, Im guessing). Smooth roasty chocolatey aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body with a pretty good sessionability about it. Carbonation runs light and refined. Dark chocolate shows a light bitterness in the harshness of how it hits my tongue. Id say nice.
Overall, really nice Baltic Porter, Im glad I finally got to try this one. Well worth my time.

Bottle. Pours black with lasting light brown head. Aroma has roasty malts, caramel, dark chocolate, coffee and liquorice. Taste is really chocolaty, both dark bitter and sweet milk chocolate. Roasted malts, coffee. Finish is dry liquorice and roasty dry. Really well balanced.
500ml from Eric TEUSINK. A little off flavor. Cardboard kind of taste. Maybe thats a lager yeast. Pretty smooth and light otherwise though. A little more barrel as it warms a little.

Bottle at home. Pours an opaque black with a tiny beige head. Quite sweet with a mellow dryness. Aromas of burnt caramel with notes of dried fruits and hints of dark chocolate and coffee. Tiny hints of alcohol. Medium to full bodied. Medium carbonation. Long bitter finish with some sweetness.

pours unclear dark brown, orange tint, with a nice reviving light beige cap, nice lacing. smooth milk chocolate, chocolate nibs - semi-sweet, burnt caramel, hint of smoke, strong coffee with a dash of cream, raisins, dark dried red fruitiness - clean lagering notes. flat carbonation, medium body - oily; warming and sweet spicy finish.

Bottle @ weekly tasting shared with Dutchdrebus and Joes. Brown color with a red-brown glare coming through, average sized beige head. Smell and taste malts, brown malts, light to moderately milk chocolate, light roast, roasted malts, some bitter. Nice one! Quite like it.

Bottle @ joes. Black colour with a medium sized beige head. Smells chocolate, sweet, roasty, vanilla, nice. Not perfect but quite nice. Tastes sweet, malts, chocolate, roasty, vanilla. Quite nice. Medium to full body, soft carbo.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark ruby red, brown blackish beer with a big creamy beige head on top. Aroma is sweet and roasty, some chocolate and roasted coffee. Flavor is sweet, very malt forward, loads of chocolate, gets more caramel in the back of the palate. Really sweet, again loads of molasses in the aftertaste. Softly carbonated, greatly balanced. Very nice beer.
Sampler at the brewery. Opaque black full bodied and creamy. Very strong anise aroma and licorice flavor, big malty finish. Nice beer but with flavoring I would not expect with this style.

Keg at CPK. Black with a small foamy brown head. Aroma is milky, pretty chocolatey with some vanilla and flowers. Body is medium, smooth, rounded. Taste is again chocolatey and lactic, creamy with some resinous flowery hops in the finish. Pretty nice stuff overall.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with coffee colored foam. Aroma is filled with chocolate, toffee. Taste is balanced not too sweet. Dark chocolate, berries, cherries and Nutella notes. Finish has relatively strong coffee bitterness. Very enjoyable!

Bottle. Nose is milk chocolate, praline, hazelnut, brown sugars, plums, fruit cake, hints of cola. Taste is chocolate, licorice, plums, cherry and red berry, fruit cake, hint of cola, lots and lots of hazelnut, hint of wood with dark chocolate and vanilla with a touch of tobacco in the finish. Mouthfeel is rich.

Baltic porter is a style I dont have a good working knowledge of, but I enjoyed this a lot.
Lots of milk chocolate and some caramelized malt. Some roast. Pours black with great carpet lacing and head. Finish mostly sweet with some bitterness. Tap at Lord hobo.

Where and how:  bottle 355ml, tasting 
Aroma: strong. Clean yeast nose. Soft wrap, hint of with vanilla. Slight hint of chocolate, toasty sides.
 Appearance : 
Top: large tanned head, rings on glass walls.
Base: brown 
Palate :  medium full bodied, drinkable with long lasting finish. 
Taste: coffee roast, too roasty feel for proper Baltic. Creamy backing makes it tad too soft as well. As in aroma, hints of vanilla. Alcohol well hidden adding gentle warmth.
 other notes  very nice imperial stout that wants to be Baltic.

Dark brown pour with small, short-lived beige head. Aroma is mild with sweet roasted malt and some coffee and cola. Taste is more complex and amplified. Starts off slightly sweet with dark roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and faint licorice. Finishes bitter with an ashy, tobacco aftertaste that was the only thing I didnt like about this beer. Smooth medium mouthfeel with low carbonation and alcohol well hidden.

500ml bottle from trade with Don. Aroma: chocolate, bourbon, woody. App: dark brown with small mocha head, little lacing. Taste and palate: full bodied, smooth, medium sweetness, medium carbonation, quite lactic, light bitter finish. Overall: well done. Quite smooth and easy to drink. A really good first beer after a 5 hours drive to a cottage in Ferme-Neuve.

355 ml. bottle split with kraddel & anderfernandez. Black small mocha head. Nose is mocha, soy sauce, umami, mushrooms, thick lager mocha. Taste is lightly sparkling mocha soy sauce, touch boozy red fruits, coffee, cacao, Thicker lager body. A touch much but overall a very interesting & nice beer.

Thnx to ships. Pours very dark and unclear coca)cola like. Small white head. Smell is sweet, dark malts. sharp. Taste is cocoa, bitter, bitter chocolate, bit boozy. Grainy. intense, goof MF and carbo. OK
Bottle bought @ Borefts Beer Festival. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, licorice, tobacco, molasses. Taste is roasty, licorice, savory, cocoa, ashy.
Tap at Fairbar. Black body. Fruity aroma with roasted malt. Rich, sweet taste with medium bitterness. Some alcohol present. Medium body. Great tasty porter.

En bouteille au Farmhouse Tap & Grill de Burlington et compagnie de François Moisan et Mademoiselle Irina. Comme les autres Framinghammer que jai eu loccasion de déguster dans le passé, cette bière est laiteuse, crémeuse et lactée à la manière dune milk stout. Arômes de vanille, de lactose intense (trop pour moi) et de café en grains. Nez intéressant qui manque toutefois de complexité, tant la vanille est omniprésente. Effervescence agréable et texture des plus soyeuses. Lalcool est présent et le liquide sestompe délicatement tel un dessert sur mon palais dorloté et bordé.

Bottle. Pours black in color with a beige head. Lots of roasted malts, light campfire, coffee and fresh licorice in aroma. Nice. Coffee, sweet chocolate and dark fruityness in taste. Smooth too, with a fairly dry and warming finish.
Bottle. Aroma of coffee, coffee, and coffee. Taste is nice: coffee, dark fruit, leather, a crisp finish, and a long bitter after-finish. Solid.
Bottle 0.355l at Stadin Panimobaari, Helsinki. Colour is black with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Coffee, some burntness, dryness, woody dryness, dark chocolate and roasted malts.Warming.

(Bottle, 0.355 l - manufacturing date missing, 20150821) The beer poured clear and nearly black. Its head was medium sized and lightly brown. Aroma had chocolate, burnt malts and sweetness. Palate was full bodied and soft with medium carbonation. Flavours were chocolate, sweetness, burnt malts, ash and bitterness. Aftertaste had dark chocolate, coffee and bitterness. A very well done roasty brew.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark black with a puffy tan head. Big aroma of roasted chocolate and coffee malts. Come hints of dark fruits as well. Definitely get a big mouthful of roasted coffee at the start with a nice and creamy chocolate and roasted malt middle. Lightly bitter on the finish.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Beershop, Stefansgade. Pours black with a creamy beige head and lacings. Roast, chocolate, coffee and a bit of berries and brown sugar. Ashy and roasted. Soft and smooth with a long finish. Lovely!
More of a sweet creamy ip not so baltic. Still good. Vg drink ability and mouthfeel. Enough hops to somewhat balance.

330ml bottle @Alus Celle, Riga. Pitch black color. Medium size, brown head, stays. Malty, slightly oxidized, roast in aroma. Sweet, caramel, roasted malts in taste. Sweet white candy and malts in aftertaste. Alcohol is quite well covered.

Thanks to Jason! Pours a deep black/brown with a loose deep tan head. The smell is milky, chocolate, alcohol hidden. The taste is as it smells with alcohol, chocolate, creamy, cocoa, licorice, fairly sweet. The body is medium+ with mild carbonation.

Many thanks to Rian for sharing! Dry and chocolate nose. The beer starts nice roasted milk-chocolate. Fresh, easy to drink with a nice roasty body. Fresh, smooth, Easy to drink with a fresh fruity dark malty aftertaste. A bit sweetish, nice, round malty, smooth. Great.
Runder malziger Beginn, der aber schnell zu süß wird. Hefig, etwas Kaffee, etwas alkoholisch. Unsüffig. Schokolade, etwas röstig. 11/10/9/7/9/9

Very nice Baltic porter, tho after some impressive IMP stouts it definitely doesnt feel bold. Moderate roast level, dark choco, light licorice, caramel, bit bready, coffee. Moderate to light sweetness, moderate bitterness.
Feels well balanced, if I would drink this at start of session, maybe would be quite impressive, now I can say its decent =]
Smooth, nice roasty porter. Big beer, but drinks easy with low booze level. Chocolate, roast, light hops, good balance between sweet and bitter. Good stuff.

Framinsteiner!! .. . Dark brown .. Mild head, good lacing .. Mild flsvours of tar and bitter cocoa .. Cuddly, nothing to interesting but I can see where this would be a good base.. . . Cats love mockingbirds, apparently

355 ml bottle.
Pours black color with a medium sized beige head. Roasted malts on the nose with some sweet milky chocolate, mild coffee notes and some faint vanilla. Chocolaty, roasty and slightly caramel-y flavor, some cocoa notes with hints of vanilla sweetness. Full-bodied and rich, nice balance, alcohol stays fairly well hidden, some warmth at the end. Very tasty.
4425

Draft @ Taphouse, Copenhagen. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel aroma. Roasted malty licorice and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty licorice and chocolate finish.

Draught at Taphouse. Low and quickly disappearing fluffy white head. Pitch black body. Walnut roasted malt cocoa caramel aroma. Coffee liquorice roasted malt flavor with a just a hint of hops bitterness. Low carbonation and a long finish.

Pours black with a beige head. Roasted malty aroma and taste, chocolate, caramel, coffee, roasted finish. Very very nice.
From tap at Taphouse. Black with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, coffee, smoke, chocokate, fruit and bourbon.

Draft. A black beer with a dark brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, and dark chocolate. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and bread, leading to a bitter finish.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Copenhagen - black pour with beige head. Roasted malty aroma and taste, chocolate, caramel, coffee, roasted finish. 

---Sent via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It make sense that Jacks Abby  a brewery that only makes lagers  would be adept at making a Baltic Porter (which, despite the name, is traditionally a lager rather than an ale). This beer is definitely to-spec in every way and on top of all that its delectable and fun to drink. What more could you ask for?

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. There was no freshness date and it cost $4.95 ($0.41 per ounce).

Appearance: Essentially opaque inky black with blood red highlights. Pours to a large, dark tan, frothy head which retains and laces extremely well.

Smell: Dark grape and dark malt with a general lager scent. Nose is actually rather mild and is probably the beers weakest feature.

Taste: Theres a difference between porters and stouts and theres a difference between Baltic and regular imperial porters  this beer is a good example of that. Sweet to be sure, but not too sweet. Theres a strong sensation of dark malt, but its not dark chocolate, coffee or burnt toast. A smooth, milky sweetness derived from the use of oats in the brew. Brown sugar is used as well (as an adjunct Im assuming), though I think I can taste it in the aftertaste. A quick, distinct, dry hop bite at the apex of the swig offers a nice balance and contrast, though I would not describe this as being a hoppy brew per se. 

Drinkability: I was a little worried that this beer was going to be a challenge to drink consider its pretty strong at 10% ABV. However, I knew it was going to be a breeze after the first sip. The mouthfeel is extremely comfortable with smooth texture and finish to match. There is no heat from the booze; nor does it feel like a beastly brew in any way. Id pair Jacks Abby Framinghammer with dessert or enjoy it as a nightcap year-round.

Score: 9/10

Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, and dark fruit. Creamy mouth feel. Flavor is roasted malt, brown sugar, vanilla, dark dried fruit, and coffee. Finish is dark roasted coffee and earthy hops. Alcohol is nicely masked.
From tap. Pours hazy dark brown toblack, small brown head. Aroma is liqourice and solid dark roasted malty. Dark malty. Liqourice, roasted malty and sweet malty. Bitter and roasted malty. Dry finish.

Draught at Ølbaren.
Black colored with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel and licorice.
Sweet and roasted chicken flavor of caramel and licorice.
Roasted finish.

6oz sample from a 12 oz bottle purchased at the beer cabin in plattsbugh. Aroma has a nice anise character with light sweetness present. A little roasted mocha, too. Slight transparent mahogany body with a small to medium tan head. Good lacing. Starts with a sweet chocolate flavor, before this becomes quite roasted in the middle. Has a little vinous alcohol kick to finish. Velvety finish.

On tap at Irreale. Brownish creamy head with good retention. Clear very dark brown colour. Aroma is roasted malt, black coffee and biscuit. Taste is rich and balanced, roasted malt, cocoa, black coffee and cookies with bitter finish. Medium body medium creamy palate.
A very good Baltic porter.
Negro opacon y espuma beis. Aromas intensos se cacao, chocolate, regaliz, vainilla y tostados. Cuerpo medio y sedoso, sabor intenso de chocolate y regaliz con final de amargor moderado tostado.
Dark pour, small tan head. Smokey nose. Lots of roasted malt, smoke. Medium body with ample booze burn.

shared bottle with a friend. bought from web order at saveur biere. poured a dark black colour with a tanned head. notes of silky smooth chocolate. oats, cacao, vanilla notes. roasted malts, licorice, toffe, roasted caramel, some dark fruits, and a slight hint of smoke, anise, medium bodied. was expecting a bit more i gues.

Bottle. Black with a medium sized beige head. Treackle, dusty grain, dry plant material. Flavour offers the same, wooden, syrupy. I Think I see what it is aiming at, but it is too sweet and rough. I dont like this much. Why the high alcohol? Whats going on here?

Une petite bouteille trouvée dans un dépanneur de létat de New-York. Une robe brune foncée. Le nez exhibe des parfums de pain noir, de terre, de malts rôtis, de cacao et, minimalement, de tabac. Le goût est bien agréable avec des saveurs de malts rôtis et grillés, de chocolat, de café et de mélasse. Lalcool est complètement invisible. En bouche, le corps crémeux est moyennement imposant. Le pétillement est doux. La finale se fait sur des notes rôties bien plaisantes. Agréable. Facile à boire. Dangereuse.
Really good Baltic porter. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate and tobacco. Smooth in mouth, light biting finish.

Bottle from Mass Liquors, Worcester Ma. Pours black with a fingers worth of dense tan head and decent lace. Cocoa nose with secondary vanilla and caramel, backed by mild pine resin. Lightly sweet flavor with everything found in the aroma plus some coffee flavor. Alcohol is noticeable, but does not intrude. Smooth creamy texture in the mouth. Full bodied. Very good.

Draught. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Coffee and roast very present. Long heavy bitter flavor. Vanilla, Licorice, roast and coffee. Long heavy bitter finish. Creamy palate. Wonderfull brew.

Tap. Black body with a small tan head. Aroma of slightly roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and licorice notes. Sweet flavor that ends up dry and with a hint of bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. A very nice Porter indeed. 🌟🌟🌟🌟

Tap at Fermentoren Aarhus. Pours black with a reddish hue. Small, nut brown head. Aroma is toasted, roasted and slight smokey malts. Alcohol seems very well hidden. Chocolate, licorice and some coffee. Taste is pretty sweet, and again very malty. Great balance, and actually not very roasty. The alcohol is more prominent here though. Medium carbonation and an oily, semi-full body.

Tap @ Fermentoren, Aarhus, 10%. Black with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, caramel, hop, little dark chocolate and a little liquorice. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, liquorice, medium sweet, little coffee, hop, notes of alcohol, warming and medium bitter.

Tap @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Almost black with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and licorice. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish with warming alcohol. Oily. 270415

Draught @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Pours black with a creamy light tan head, nice lacings. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, licorice, Flavor is rather dry, roasted, malty, caramel, coffee, molasses, rich chocolate, licorice. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, dry and light bitter finish with some warming alcohol. 260415

Tap @ fermentoren. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate, dark roasted malts, liquorice, weak smoke and tobacco. The taste is rather roasty but also has some sweet malts, chocolate, liquorice, savory notes, cocoa and weak ash/smoke. A nice baltic porter indeed.

Tap. Pours black with soapy lasting light brown head. Aroma has roasty malts, caramel, dark chocolate, coffee anis and liquorice. Slight oxidation. Taste is really chocolaty, both dark bitter and sweet milk chocolate. Some burnt sugar. Roasted malts, coffee. Finish is dry liquorice and roasty dry. Really well balanced, though slight alcoholic finish. Would like to age this one!

Bottle from SJ. Im starting to like this company. Nice roasted / chocolate malts, some smoke, brown sugar and vanilla. It really is well balanced with a medium body. Excellent representation of the style.
Bomber into a taster. Bold dark coffee presence. Bold frontal stout presence, huge prominent abv touch. Wow, huge

Draft at Moriartys. Top of a keg. Black pour (actually a very dark clear brown under bright light.) Thick tan head. Rings of lace. Silky body. Dark cocoa. Mocha. The high ABV is well hidden. Smooth - but maybe too much so. It needs more of an edge.
Black pour, great brown head. great roasty sweet aroma, flavor of chocolate, cocoa, oats, great sweet smooth body

Aroma is of coffee and chocolate. Body is pitch black with a thin tan head. Taste is heavy dry chocolate with coffee mixed in. Hint of caramel sweetness in the background though you have to pay attention to notice. Medium bitterness. Warms the palate with its heavy 10% ABV otherwise its power is not noticeable. Thick and slick feeling so best enjoyed slowly. Enjoyable and well balanced. Id be happy to have many more of these.
12oz chugged in under 10 seconds. Notes of thick Alabama black wood and full metal jacket. Coffe. Round with figs. Lifts. Easy chugger.

Black oily pour. Aroma of hops, caramel, chocolate and vanilla. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, hops and citrus. Oily and thick, stout like. Alcohol is hidden well. Overall very good Baltic porter.

Solid beer. Poured a deep dark brown, with a foamy beige head. Aroma is just okay, dark breads, earhty, ight roast and a hint of chocolate coffee. Flavor is earthty, dirt, well done toast, burmt pudding. Creamy body, soft carbonation.
12 oz bottle from Rosey. Smells really good, chocolate and malt. Really nice vanilla notes with yeast. Looks a little thinner than your average porter. Really nice, not exceptional.
4 oz pour on draft at Jacks Abby. Black with tan head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, light smoke. Tastes of roast, dark chocolate, smoke, light dark fruit. Medium-full body with a dry finish.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2017 Opaque,dark copper appearance, tall, staying and loose foam. Medium body, silky, flavorful, bright and hot mouthfeel, good length, pleasant, clean and graceful finish. Sweet then bitter, tart acidity, well balanced. Coffee, malt, vanilla, uva de cavalo. Delicious lager/porter character, easy drinking. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Julios. Poured into a snifter. Jet back color. Frothy tan head that settles to a thin lace. Huge dark roasty malts- layers of them. Decent piney bitterness followed by a burn. Thick and chewy!

Beautiful beer. Black pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of a very smooth chocolate with s taste that matches the aroma perfectly. Slightly chalky finish. But delicious beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Bourbon, Dark Mildly Smoked Malts, Mild Chocolate

Appearance: Dark Opaque Hue, Passes Almost No Light, Thin Off White Head Ring, Mild Lacing

Taste: Bourbon, Brown Sugar, Sweet Chocolate Malts, Mildly Smokey

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium to Full Bodied, Mildly Boozy, Mildly Sweet

APPEARANCE - Ridiculously black with light colored head. Light does not penetrate this beer.
NOSE - Scent of bourbon - kind of expected.
FLAVOR  too much bourbon off the start. Any benefit of the porter or roastiness is overpowered from the start. Even after the beer warms up, the bourbon overpowers any other flavor. 
NOTES  Its definitely a bourbon barrel aged beer, but that part overpowers any other flavor that one may enjoy from this one.

A - pours nearly opaque cola brown with white ring of head. S - nice nose. Roasted malts, nice rounded graininess, wet coffee grounds, very light hop profile. Hints of vanilla, molasses, and carob. M - medium body with a great balance of sweet and dark. Bitter end. Nice mf. T - follows the nice well. Roasted malts, coffee grounds and grains on the front. Palate has cola syrup, molasses, coffee grounds, vanilla. End is bitter grassy. O - nice balanced porter, be it a little bitter on the end. 3.6

light beige head leaves some lacing. coffee coloured. aroma is boozy, vanilla, coconut. taste like aroma, roasted malts, chocolate aftertaste is bitter chocolate. very soft silky mouthfeel, medium carbonation. lovely beer. bottle 50cl

Bottle: Thanks, Matt. Oily, mostly black body with dark brown edges & a thin, tan head resting on top. Aroma of moderately roasted chocolate malts, light black cherry & prune, dense brown sugar, & a touch of boozy robustness. Flavor is not quite as roasty, but still has a decent amount of dark malts. Lots of toasted nuts, brown sugar, & a large back-end of rich, dark fruits, prunes, dates. Light hints of anise & some booze lingering in the finish. Medium body.

Tasting at Matts Black color with large beige head. The aroma is very nice, it has bread and biscuits too; mild roasted malts, cocoa. The body is medium strong, its fairly roasty for a Baltic Porter, but the work with the malts is very appreciated, with beautiful chocolate, cocoa and bread notes; warming alcohol.Excellent.

500mL bottle, pours a deep dark brown / black with a small beige head. Nose of cocoa, a touch of coffee and a touch of roasted malt. Flavour is very well-balanced, with notes of moderate roasted malt, unsweetened cocoa powder, a touch of coffee and a warming effect that finishes. Very dry, without any residual sweetness, but with quite a pronounced warming effect. Dryer than usual for the style. Very nice stuff.
500 ml. bottle. Pours almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is the same. Very well made. Very tasty.
Bottle shared by Bobby. Pours dark brown tan head. Nose/taste of vanilla, roasted oats, cocoa, roast chocolate and coffee. Medium body. Crisp.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Chocolate, roasted aromas. Flavors are roasted dry malts, dark tones.

Pours black with a huge mocha head...nice lacing and retention. Aroma has nice roastiness with chocolate, mild ash, and a touch of anise...almost root beery in a way. Flavor follows suit...slightly sweet and then turning to roasty bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is roasty with hints of anise and dark chocolate.

Bottle split at Bruces pad, thanks to LKS, 12/05/14.
Black with a moderate tan swirl.
Nose is bitter roast, dark chocolate fudge, coffee grinds, light booze.
Taste comprises burnt toffee, spice, dark chocolate, light roast.
Medium bodied +, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid BalticPorter.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle shared in London - picked up at the brewery. Pours clear brown with a frothy, beige head. The nose has a bit of milk chocolate, dark bread, light dark fruits. Medium sweet flavor, more milk chocolate, light burnt wood, subtle earth, raisins. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Moderately sweet to finish, some toasty earth, decent roast, cocoa. Very nice. Well balanced, quite drinkable,

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2014 Bottle, thanks to Leighton. It pours near black with a small tan head. The nose is earthy, roasted malt, milky cocoa, treacle, mild acidity, milky candy and brown sugar. The taste is sweet, tangy, earthy, warming alcohol, toffee, toasty, treacle, cola and brown sugar with a dry, sweetish finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. Solid baltic porter.
I liked this much more than the Vanilla version. This is drier. Same thick palate, this time with a noticeable flavor and aroma of roasted malt and some sugar. Good.

At my place over an empty pool with group. Pours black with layer of white cream. Aroma is light, clean, smooth lightly roasted malts. Taste is smooth lightly roasts malt, very drinkable and agreeable.
Pours a dark brown with light white head. Biscuit, chocolate and some malt; follows onto the palate. Finishes sweet.

Dark brown color with a creamy tan head. I didnt pick up much from the aroma but the flavor is robust roasted chocolate malt, touches of vanilla, milk chocolate, boozy but at 10-12% to be expected. Almost silky mouthfeel. Nice beer

Draft. Pours black with thin white head that dissipates. Mild chocolate aroma over little carbonation. A bit boozy with chocolate and vanilla flavors. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wow, I always thought the BA version was amazingly smooth and layered because of the barrel, but after drinking this I was pleasantly surprised just how good this base beer is ! Roasted chocolate malt, silky mouthfeel, touches of vanilla, milk chocolate and a long smooth finish. Really tasty brew !
Dark brown almost black. Big tan head. Plenty of lacing. Roasty malt aroma. Creamy malt flavor with some mild roasted notes. Sweet finish.
This is great. Aroma is light cocoa, coffee, and heath bar. Tastes so smooth and full of cocoa, oats, and toffee. Great beer.

500ml bottle thanks to NHhophead, pours dark rich brown with light edges and a finger of eggshell head. Nose is nutty cocoa and cold coffee beans. Taste is coffee, cocoa, almond, nuts, cream. A touch thin. Hides the 10% well. Finish is medium bitter dusty chocolate and subtle vanilla notes. Solid.

Bottle to snifter. Thanks to Dan. Somewhat thick and black with a nice tan head that fades to a ring. Dark and roasty. Some coffee and licorice. Roasty malt goodness. Just a bit of alcohol bite. Slight hop bitterness.
.
500. Thanks d! Pours an opaque black with no head or lace. Big sweet coffee and licorice nose. Creamy thick body with soft carb. Roasty coffee mid palate. Long rich coffee finish.
Black, silky, boozy, sweet but balanced with a great hop bitterness. Chocolate and coffee in the flavor. Great porter!
Bottle..Pour is dark black with a thin head..Nose is chocolate, dry, bitter, chocolate powder..Taste is spice, chocolate powder, dry, bitter,

Great tasting porter smooth with hint of chocolate and oatmeal. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours opaque black with off-white head. Smells of coffee, chocolate, and astringency. Drinks smoothly with mild lingering hop bitterness. Medium to full bodied. Tastes of coffee, milk, and pepper.

500 ml bottle thanks to WillRunForBeer. Pours pitch black with a small head that fades to a bubbly ring. Aromas are sweet cream, brown sugar, oats, nuts, and roasted malt. Taste is sweet brown sugar and cream at first with some chocolate and cocoa. Bitter roast and hops take over in the finish. Medium to thick body, creamy mouthfeel. Abv well hidden but you can tell this its big by the intensity. A little sweet but this is a very smooth and tasty beer. Take away some brown sugar and it would be top notch.

.5 liter bottle. It pours an attractive dark brown color with a nice lasting tan head. The aroma is sharply roasted with dry grains, toast, coffee and a tiny hint of graham cracker. The flavor is awesome with some burnt sugar, marshmallow, alcohol, dark chocolate. The brown sugar really comes through strong. Very silky mouthfeel. Maybe a tad too much sugar for my liking and pretty strong alcohol, but thats kind of in step with others Ive had from this style. Nice beer.

Black pour, obviously. No highlights at all. Creamy tan head. Not a ton of aroma. Light nutty and sweet. Sweet and smooth up front. Strong roasts dryness in the back. Alcohol warming is serious at times. Cocoa and a slight vinious note in the back. Absolutely smooth as silk. Intense yet delicate. Impressive.

Pours a dark motor oil colored blackish brown with a minimal tan head. Smells of roasted coffee and chocolate and taste is the same with some hop bitterness and malts.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The beer pours practically like motor oil, thick and black with just a hint of coffee browness reflecting back at the eyes. It forms a beautiful, dark tan head of creamy, small bubbles that settle around a fingers width above the glass. In body, the beers clarity is hard to discern, seeing as how it is totally opaque. The beer seems thick and viscous, but clear of any particles or cloudiness, but that is just going off of what I saw pour into my glass. On the nose, the beer smells magnificent. Dark roasted coffee with a thick nuance of dark fruits like brown sugar and raisins, plums, and just a touch of sweet cherries. Soft char, and a nuttiness also make their way into the nose, along with spicy licorice. Touches of caramel and toffee do blend in with the coffee as the beer swirls around the glass. On the tongue, the beer tastes initially sweet, but then dries out beautifully into gentle coffee bitters with touches of dark fruitiness, and even a light sense of spice. Acidity is light to nonexistent on the palate. Alcohol is just an afterthought at the end of the sip, providing a light heat and spice to the finish, which is very impressive given the beers 10% ABV. In flavor, the beer begins as sweet bread, but swiftly unfurls into light char, rich coffee, dark and bitter chocolate, and touches of molasses. Burnt raisins and brown sugar come to mind as the sip hits the mid-palate, along with a nice nuttiness that I also found in Jacks Evil Brew, and even a touch of toffee on the finish. In the third quarter of the sip is a burst of spice blending a touch of cinnamon with licorice for a nice burst of flavor. The finish is strong but muddled. The flavoring is peculiarly light with coffee, and brings more spice, light alcoholic heat, and even a touch of cherry into play on the palate. There is even a bit of meaty flavoring on the end of the finish, almost like a Christmas Ham The aftertaste is more expected with roasted malt, coffee, and char lingering on the tongue. I love this beer until the finish, and though it is not awful, the muddling has me confused. In the mouth, the beer feels full bodied and smooth. Velvety carbonation of an above average rate helps to coat the tongue in softness as the beer displays its chewy, yet smooth quality. The mouth is left wet all over with a lingering roast-bitter tingle and a slight warmth in the gullet. Overall, this is a great thick beer that is perfect for sipping in front of a fire. I wasnt quite as fond of it as I was of its barrel-aged variant, mostly because of the oddness of the finish. The flavors are not awful by any stretch, but merely peculiar and out of place with what I was expecting. This is a good beer that gets even better after sitting down in a barrel.

In short: A rich porter on the roasty chocolaty side. Good beer.
How: Growler shared at post HF FoFA 2013 party.
The look: Very dark burgundy (almost black) topped by a small beige head.
In long: Big malty dark caramel nose a bit on the choclaty/cacao side of things. In mouth the beer offers a full sumptuous body with a good carbonation. Taste is rich malts, dark caramel, black chocolate, roast, tobacco leafs. No alcohol presence and sweetness sensation lower than expected. Felt quite drinkable to me for a 10% brew. Good brew for malts lovers. Its kind of sad to think that all the time I spent in my life listening to people talk about the balance of a beer is time I will never get back.
A very well-made porter. Lagering gives it the silky-smooth mouthfeel that separates this from the more hopped varieties of the style coming from the States. Alcohol is well-integrated. This works.

From the 25 fl. oz. bottle. No date of bottling or expiration. The pour is black basically with a long lasting tan head. Those toasted and roasted malt character plays up big in the taste with a little bit of malty note. Slight smoke. Body is medium to full. The taste has a definitive dark malt character with a modest bitterness at the end. Interesting to say the least.

Sampled at the brewery. Pours near black with a beige heae. Aroma of roasted, chocolate, and coffee from the malts plus floral hops. Flavor has a nice blend of the malts. The 2013 version was more crisp while the 2012 was mellowed and smooth. Smooth texture. A really good beer.

16oz bottle or whatever size it was. Poured a black color with the consistency of cola with a medium-tan head. Aroma was malty notes, brown sugar, plenty of roasted character. Flavor was malt, caramel notes. A bit boozy, pleasant, but just kind of here.
growler at the hill farmstead event, good dark roasty characteristics, one of the best ballanced baltic porters ive ever had

Bottle with brian, pours dark brown with off white head. Aromas and  taste of perfect smoke, chocolate roast, barrel, coffee, toffee. A little hot even for 10 percent. Slightly dry in finish. Nice baltic porter.
Tap.   Real nice potent cocoa.  Dark chocolate.  Touch of fig.  Clean.  Pleasant roast.   Real nice.

Draft @ Ward Eight, Lowell  MA. A slighter darker than coca cola with thick, full tan head, that coated the side of the mug on the way down. Nice roasted malts, chocolate aroma, with molasses, and a hint of smoke. The flavor has charred malts at the core, with lots of roasted grain, coffee notes and nice amount of chocolate through the sip. The alcohol isnt apparent at all until just after the swallow. Nice warming on the way down. Medium-bodied but leaning on full. This beer definitely didnt disappoint. Layers of roasted malts. Full of flavor and another great beer from Jacks Abby.

Big thanks to Alex for the Growler! Pours a clear dark brown with a with a dark brown head that dissipates to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma has a combination of dark grain and roasted malts with a hint of chocolate. Flavor has more of a combination of roasted malts and dark chocolate that gives a slightly bitter finish.

Sampled at GABF 2012.  Pours a watery black with some creamy beige head.  Malty nose, toasted bread, brown sugar, licorice, rubber.  Flavor is sweet, malty, toasted bread, caramel, light coffee.  Medium bodied, dry finish.
Pours black into a shaker. Mocha head with excellent retention recedes to coat surface. Dark chocolate aromas. Dark smoky chocolate front to back with a lasting espresso finish.
